title: Servicios y Cursos
text:
Workshops and Services
Using renewable energy sources has generated the need, both for governmental and private institutions, to know the great benefits of this technology, as well as the basic technical concepts to determine its potential and viability. At the IER we contribute to the training of human resources specialized in the subject and we provide solutions in this regard. In this context, the Wind Energy Group of the UNAM Renewable Energy Institute offers the following services:
Courses in Wind Energy - Unidad de Educación Contínua


Energía Eólica para todos

Course name:
Energía Eólica
Course leaders:

PhD. Osvaldo Rodríguez Hernández

General Objective
At the end of the course, the fundamental technical concepts related to Wind Energy will have been addressed.
Specific Objectives

To understand the national and global context of Wind Energy.
To identify the methodology and basic requirements for the development of wind projects.
To understand the sub-systems as well as the basic mechanical and aerodynamic principles of a wind turbine.
To understand the main strategies for integration into the electrical grid.

Syllabus

Background of Wind Energy
Basic concepts for the techno-economic evaluation of a wind energy project.
Basic principles of wind energy extraction.
Basic technical principles of the mechanical and aerodynamic components of wind turbines.
Basic principles for the integration of wind systems into the grid.

Who is it aimed at: Aimed at professionals, executives and decision makers interested in the fundamental technical aspects of wind energy.
Course hours: from 20 to 40 hours.
Number of participants: Flexible and adapted to the needs of the applicant.
Material included: Supplementary course material.
For more information, please contact the Secretaría de Educación Continua at: uec@ier.unam.mx
At the end of the course, certificates of participation will be issued.

Services
Given the wide range of wind services on the market, at IER-UNAM we offer technical consultancy on the following topics:

Technical feasibility of the site for wind power.
Consulting on the development of measurement campaigns.
Consulting on the selection of technologies for the site.
Comparison and evaluation of proposals.
Analysis of integration into the electrical grid.
Design of energy conversion systems based on power electronics, with specific applications in renewable sources.
Consulting on project supervision.

title: Grupo Energía Eólica
text:
About
The Wind energy Group is a recent creation group with research lines in consolidation; it comprises five researchers, undergrad and grad students in renewable energy engineering. The group has experience in international collaboration with the University of Reading (one Newton Fund project), The University of Strathclyde in the United Kingdom, and DTU Delft in the Netherlands, which are still active. The main research lines with experimental equipment and facilities are classified as follows:


Resource assessment modeling



Analysis of meteorological modeling into wind power applications. In this area, the main goal is to assess the reliability of reanalysis data and dynamical modeling to represent wind power conditions, power production, and capacity factors. The main challenges are understanding variability and complementarity with solar and storage systems in different Mexican regions to model high renewable energy penetration scenarios according to electric demand. In addition, forecasting is also a challenge, and it may be based on meteorological modeling to estimate 24-hour forecasting accordingly for the Mexican electric market. Finally, to increase the spatial resolution of dynamical modeling to study the interaction between wind turbine wakes in wind farm arrays or small wind turbine interactions with the environment.




Computational fluid dynamics



The group develops numerical codes to solve turbulent flow mass and momentum conservation equations. We consider the Reynolds Averaged Navier-Stokes (RANS) formulation and we explore various alternatives for specifying the boundary conditions and the closure problem. Recently, we have considered developing models for fluid-structure interactions to understand the mechanical energy transfer from the wind to a system that modifies its position due to the aerodynamic interaction. In our context, the obvious application of these physical conditions is the wind interaction with turbine blades. Also, we are interested in the possibility of using artificial intelligence tools to solve the closure problem in turbulence, and other machine learning tools to control the dynamics of wind turbines.




Experimental aerodynamics



The group has designed and recently built a small wind tunnel with modular, individually-controlled small fans that drive the flow through the working section. It is expected that the time-average velocity profile and turbulence level can be controlled to at least partially mimic the dynamics in the atmospheric boundary layer. The goal is to test the performance of scaled wind turbines under conditions similar to those in the earth’s atmosphere. It is expected that the observations in the wind tunnel will provide experimental information to verify the numerical models.




Data science



Artificial Intelligence methods are applied to analyze problems related to wind dynamics, power generation and distributed generation, based on datasets: Clustering methods to classify wind states in sites; network theory and machine learning to multiscale evaluation of regional and national wind states; neural networks to forecast power generation and electricity demand to integrate smart microgrids.




Power electronics



Modeling, analysis, design, simulation, and implementation of power electronic devices, are applied in energy conditioning for the wind turbine integration at the electrical networks, generating an energy conversion system. Low-scale experimental prototypes validate the energy conversion systems’ functionality and robustness. The test systems’ technical characteristics are reflected, whose analysis is carried out in real-time using the OPAL-RT Technologies® simulator, test-bench for wind turbines, power electronics devices, and an electrical network emulator.




Wind turbines integration at the electrical networks



Analysis of the problems inherent to integrating many wind turbines in the electrical grids and the management of their contribution (regulating voltage and frequency, wind farms operation, etc.) to guarantee the sustainability and security of supply. In addition, the technical challenges associated with integrating wind power into power systems are addressed. These challenges include the effects of wind power on the electrical system, the operating cost, power quality, and power imbalances (grid stability). Finally, solutions are presented to improve the management of wind generation and increase its penetration in the whole of electricity production.

title: Especialista en Eólica
text:
Academic Training
Bachelor of Engineering in Renewable Energy
The Bachelor of Engineering in Renewable Energy (LIER) is a multidisciplinary degree that arises as a response to the great energy challenges and global environmental problems, which demand professionals who meet the needs of the energy sector and sustainable development, with social responsibility. This degree is carried out in collaboration with the UNAM Institute of Engineering (II-UNAM). It lasts 4 years and its curriculum is executed every semester. Specialists in the areas of photothermal systems, photovoltaic systems, materials design, refrigeration systems and heat pumps, geothermal energy, wind energy, biofuels, fuel cells, energy in buildings, energy planning, energy sustainability and environmental impact participate. In addition to this infrastructure of human resources, II-UNAM also has a solid academic staff with experience and recognition in the areas of photothermal systems, hydraulics, ocean energy, energy in buildings and biofuels.



Curriculum Map


Postgraduate in Engineering
The IER is home to the Postgraduate Program in Energy Knowledge Engineering (PIcE), whose mission is to train excellent researchers capable of generating new knowledge and conceiving technical strategies and methodologies that solve key and priority problems in the development of the country. This Postgraduate Program includes study plans for Master’s and Doctorate degrees recognized by the National Program of Quality Postgraduate Studies (PNPC) of CONACYT, with the Master’s Program being certified as a Consolidated National Program, while the Doctorate Program is certified as an International Competence Program, which is the highest level of accreditation. Today it offers academic training to 67 Master’s students and 97 Doctorate students.



The disciplinary fields in the Postgraduate Degree in Engineering (Energy) are: Bioclimatic Design, Renewable Sources and Energy Systems with the following subdisciplines: - Bioclimatic Design - Bioclimatic design of buildings - Renewable Sources - Geothermal energy - Solar photothermal energy - Solar photovoltaic energy - Energy Systems - Energy economics - Energy and environment - Processes and efficient use of energy


Master’s Degree in Engineering
The Master’s Degree in Engineering (Energy) (MIcE) is unique in the country and is oriented towards scientific and scientific-practical research that allows the training of high-level professionals. The mission of the master’s degree is to train quality researchers, capable of generating new knowledge and conceiving technical strategies and methodologies that solve key and priority problems in the development of the country. This program has a roster of 59 tutors distributed among the different university institutions participating in the postgraduate program, that is, the Engineering Institute (II UNAM), the Faculty of Engineering (FI UNAM) and the IER UNAM.
PhD in Engineering
The PhD in Engineering (Energy) (DI cE) aims to train independent researchers with the ability to propose and carry out original and cutting-edge research (theoretical and applied), disseminate the results of such research and apply the knowledge generated to the technological development of the country. This program has 61 tutors, 40 of whom belong to the IER UNAM and the rest to the FI UNAM and II UNAM. It is important to mention that within the postgraduate program, there is experience with double degree graduation systems with European Universities.
